source.title: 96-well Plate Growth Curve Setup

authors.name: Panagiotis Papastamoulis
authors.affiliation: Athens University of Economics and Business, Greece

steps.data: {"blocks":[{"key":"6ukcb","text":"Harvest and dilute spores in PBS+0.01% Tween to 4*105 spores\/mL.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":52,"length":2,"style":"sup"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"1u5n7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6uad7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b40kh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[],"guid":"E93DDF80934A11E99C188F6CD56748A2","id":760714,"previous_id":null,"previous_guid":null,"section":"Plate preparation"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4a0s8","text":"Aliquot 5 uL of this spore stock per well of a CytoOne 96-well plate (Starlab) non-coated, this will be overlayed with 195 uL of liquid media to a total volume of 200 uL.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dl3p9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"58d5d","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":1,"key":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"auqkf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"33sjh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"key":"dqe2m","text":"This equals to 2000 spores (absolute) per well. 1000 spores or 500 spores are possible to use, but result in more variance within replicates.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}}],"guid":"6265A690934B11E99C188F6CD56748A2","id":760717,"previous_id":760714,"previous_guid":"E93DDF80934A11E99C188F6CD56748A2","section":"Plate preparation"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"hu","text":"In the Manchester Fungal Infection Group we either use a Powerwave X-2 with KC software or a BioTek platereader. Set this up to run for    at    to measure OD600 every 10 minutes. Take a blank reading before running the plate and preheat the machine. Run your experiment.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":158,"length":4,"style":"sub"}],"entityRanges":[{"offset":136,"length":1,"key":0},{"offset":142,"length":1,"key":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"37a8k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9m09p","text":"This will result in a \"growth curve\".","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9r27q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"51e9r","text":"Extract or manipulate the data to look like attached (txt file format).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"duration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":0,"guid":"2F119D80936E11E9B347F76D97504271","label":"","protocol_name":"Growth curve 96-well plate setup","step_number":"3","step_guid":"C3E16E00936D11E9B347F76D97504271","start":null,"pause":null,"duration":172800}},{"type":"temperature","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"id":0,"guid":"349EF8B0936E11E9B347F76D97504271","unit":10,"label":"","protocol_name":"Growth curve 96-well plate setup","step_number":"3","step_guid":"C3E16E00936D11E9B347F76D97504271","temperature":"37"}}],"guid":"C3E16E00936D11E9B347F76D97504271","id":760758,"previous_id":760999,"previous_guid":"6B19B2D0936F11E987116590BFB9C228","section":"Machine setup"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"94hlu","text":"Fill the space between the wells with either media or H2O. This will avoid an \"edge effect\", where the wells around the edge of the plate show increased growth compared to other wells.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":55,"length":1,"style":"sub"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[],"guid":"2F7D1410936F11E987116590BFB9C228","id":760997,"previous_id":760717,"previous_guid":"6265A690934B11E99C188F6CD56748A2","section":"Plate preparation"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d8eep","text":"Cover the 96 well plate with a breathable cover to allow gas exchange.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[],"guid":"6B19B2D0936F11E987116590BFB9C228","id":760999,"previous_id":760997,"previous_guid":"2F7D1410936F11E987116590BFB9C228","section":"Plate preparation"}

However, the solid media environment does not accurately mimic the environment encountered during infection (ie the mammalian lung). Previously, we have developed a methodology to perform liquid growth assays in time for A. fumigatus and other filamentous fungi including analysis via mathematical modelling.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":345,"length":13,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"72toe","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5m2dd","text":"This protocol is designed for Aspergillus species (and other filamentous fungi) to generate growth curves in liquid media in a 96-well plate. This can be done in high-throughput to generate 96 growth curves per run.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":30,"length":12,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

You can find the script below that you need in order to read your raw data-files, format the file names like this:
plate1-Rep1.txt  plate1-Rep3.txt  plate2-Rep2.txt  plate3-Rep1.txt  plate3-Rep3.txt  plate4-Rep2.txt  plate5-Rep1.txt  plate5-Rep3.txt
plate1-Rep2.txt  plate2-Rep1.txt  plate2-Rep3.txt  plate3-Rep2.txt  plate4-Rep1.txt  plate4-Rep3.txt  plate5-Rep2.txt

source.body: Make sure the different replicates are in different files. However, the location in the plate should be exactly the same (ie. A5 should be A5, B2 should be B2). If this is not the case or replicates are on one plate, transform the original files to match this format. Furthermore, titles of the wells should exactly be the same!

source.description:
Apply the code below. Change the number of reps and plates to your experiment (top two lines). Make sure the data is formatted as above.
The final object returned after applying the code is the list `myDataList`.

source.command: This is to process 96-well growth data to match formatting required for the BEAST CRAN package. Different replicates from different files are merged into one dataframe.

source.description:
Install BEAST software from CRAN into R studio.
https://rdrr.io/cran/beast/man/beast-package.html
Manual can be found:
https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/beast/beast.pdf

Run beast. The top is an example for data included in the package (don't run if you want to run your own data). Example dataset is attached to run.
If you want an example first, run the top example and reload your data with the code above.
For your own data run, only run the code from Run MCMC sampler and Print and Plot output lines.
Assume that the observed data consists of N time-series, each one consisting of R variables (or replicates) measured at T consecutive time-points.
The input of the main function beast should be given in the form of a list myDataList with the following attributes:
• length(myDataList) should be equal to R, that is, the number of variables (or replicates)
• dim(myDataList)[[1]],..., dim(myDataList)[[R]] should be all T×N, that is, rows and columns should correspond to time-points and different series, respectively.
Then, a basic usage of the package consists of the following commands:
• beastRun <- beast( myDataList = myDataList )
• print(beastRun)
• plot(beastRun)
which correspond to running the MCMC sampler, printing and plotting output summaries, respectively.
Below a toy-example is given which reproduces Figure 1 of the paper.
> library('beast') # load package
> data("FungalGrowthDataset") # load dataset
> myIndex <- c(392, 62, 3, 117) # run the sampler only for the
# specific subset of time-series
> set.seed(1) # optional
# Run MCMC sampler with the default number of iterations (nIter =70000):
> run_mcmc <- beast(myDataList = FungalGrowthDataset, subsetIndex = myIndex,
zeroNormalization = TRUE)
# Print output:
> print(run_mcmc)
# Plot output to file: "beast_plot.pdf"
> plot(run_mcmc, fileName = "beast_plot_fungal_data.pdf", timeScale=1/6, xlab = "hours", ylab = "growth")
The complexity prior distribution with parameter gammaParameter = 2 is the default prior assumption imposed on the number of change-points.
Smaller (larger) values of gammaParameter will a-priori support larger (respectively: smaller) number of change-points.
Full documentation of the package is given in
https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/beast/beast.pdf.
This should result in a PDF file containing all curves combined clustered in groups with different change-points and individual curves for each isolate.

description:
Generally, growth assays for filamentous fungi have been performed on solid media, either as dilution series or spot tests. However, the solid media environment does not accurately mimic the environment encountered during infection (ie the mammalian lung). Previously, we have developed a methodology to perform liquid growth assays in time for A. fumigatus and other filamentous fungi including analysis via mathematical modelling.
This protocol is designed for Aspergillus species (and other filamentous fungi) to generate growth curves in liquid media in a 96-well plate. This can be done in high-throughput to generate 96 growth curves per run.
